channel.title: Constitutional
channel.description:
With the writing of the Constitution in 1787, the framers set out a young nation’s highest ideals. And ever since, we’ve been fighting over it — what is in it and what was left out. At the heart of these arguments is the story of America.
As a follow-up to the popular Washington Post podcast “Presidential,” reporter Lillian Cunningham returns with this series exploring the Constitution and the people who framed and reframed it — revolutionaries, abolitionists, suffragists, teetotalers, protesters, justices, presidents – in the ongoing struggle to form a more perfect union across a vast and diverse land.
channel.itunes:author: The Washington Post
channel.itunes:summary:

channel.itunes:subtitle: Constitutional

item.title: Episode 07: Congress and citizens
item.description: Is it a feature or a bug of the amendment process that an idea of James Madison's, more than 200 years ago, could be recently resurrected and etched into the U.S. Constitution?
item.dc:creator: The Washington Post
item.itunes:author: The Washington Post
item.itunes:subtitle: Is it a feature or a bug of the amendment process that an idea of James Madison's, more than 200 years ago, could be recently resurrected and etched into the U.S. Constitution?
item.itunes:summary: Is it a feature or a bug of the amendment process that an idea of James Madison's, more than 200 years ago, could be recently resurrected and etched into the U.S. Constitution?

item.title: Episode 06: Senate and states
item.description: When the United States changed its process for electing senators, did that lead to a decline in state power? Or did it instead bring us closer to a "more perfect union"?
item.dc:creator: The Washington Post
item.itunes:author: The Washington Post
item.itunes:subtitle: When the United States changed its process for electing senators, did that lead to a decline in state power? Or did it instead bring us closer to a "more perfect union"?
item.itunes:summary: When the United States changed its process for electing senators, did that lead to a decline in state power? Or did it instead bring us closer to a "more perfect union"?

item.title: Episode 05: Gender
item.description: From the American Revolution through today, women have been leading a long-burning rebellion to gain rights not originally guaranteed under the Constitution.
item.dc:creator: The Washington Post
item.itunes:author: The Washington Post
item.itunes:subtitle: From the American Revolution through today, women have been leading a long-burning rebellion to gain rights not originally guaranteed under the Constitution.
item.itunes:summary: From the American Revolution through today, women have been leading a long-burning rebellion to gain rights not originally guaranteed under the Constitution.

item.title: Episode 04: Race
item.description: As powerful as it was to change the Constitution after the Civil War, and enshrine racial equality into our governing document, that wasn’t enough to change the reality of life in America.
item.dc:creator: The Washington Post
item.itunes:author: The Washington Post
item.itunes:subtitle: As powerful as it was to change the Constitution after the Civil War, and enshrine racial equality into our governing document, that wasn’t enough to change the reality of life in America.
item.itunes:summary: As powerful as it was to change the Constitution after the Civil War, and enshrine racial equality into our governing document, that wasn’t enough to change the reality of life in America.

item.title: Episode 03: Nationality
item.description: What makes someone American? A landmark Supreme Court case in 1898, involving a child born in San Francisco to Chinese immigrant parents, would help answer that question.
item.dc:creator: The Washington Post
item.itunes:author: The Washington Post
item.itunes:subtitle: What makes someone American? A landmark Supreme Court case in 1898, involving a child born in San Francisco to Chinese immigrant parents, would help answer that question.
item.itunes:summary: What makes someone American? A landmark Supreme Court case in 1898, involving a child born in San Francisco to Chinese immigrant parents, would help answer that question.

item.title: Episode 02: Ancestry
item.description: This "we the people" episode explores indigenous rights. In 1879, a case involving Chief Standing Bear came before a Nebraska courtroom and demanded an answer to the question: Are Native Americans considered human beings under the U.S. Constitution?
item.dc:creator: The Washington Post
item.itunes:author: The Washington Post
item.itunes:subtitle: This "we the people" episode explores indigenous rights. In 1879, a case involving Chief Standing Bear came before a Nebraska courtroom and demanded an answer to the question: Are Native Americans considered human beings under the U.S. Constitution?

item.title: Episode 01: Framed
item.description: In the premier episode of “Constitutional,” we go back in time to that hot Philadelphia summer in 1787 when a group of revolutionary Americans debated, drank and together drafted the U.S. Constitution. Episode guests include historian Erica Dunbar, National Archivist David Ferriero, the Library of Congress’s Julie Miller and the National Constitution Center’s Jeffrey Rosen.
item.dc:creator: The Washington Post
item.itunes:author: The Washington Post

item.title: Introducing 'Constitutional'
item.description: Preview The Washington Post's newest podcast, a narrative series about the revolutionary figures who shaped America's story. Subscribe now to get the first episode when it launches July 24.
item.dc:creator: The Washington Post
